Award.AwardTitle: Small-Molecule Vapor-Deposited Materials for Integrated Nonlinear Optics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: Nonlinear optical materials enable the interaction between multiple photons, allowing light signals to control other light signals. Such capabilities are important for continuous developments in optical computing and in optical telecommunication networks such as those that today transmit everything from TV channels to the Internet. This research project aims at studying and developing a new fundamental paradigm that consists in using small organic molecules to build high-quality "plastic" nonlinear optical materials that can then be used with current and future technologies to provide important new all-optical data-processing capabilities at ultrafast speeds. The interdisciplinary nature of the research and its vertically integrated approach (from molecules to materials to devices) provide a varied training ground for the education of undergraduate and graduate students, who learn to use modern laser systems and to control (in wavelength and in time) short optical pulses, while at the same time being exposed to chemistry on one side and engineering on the other.

Technical Description: The project aims at advancing the understanding of fundamental nonlinear optical properties and how they translate from molecules to the solid-state, and at creating flexible organic nonlinear optical materials by vapor deposition of optimized molecules into dense supramolecular assemblies with a high optical quality. The research focuses on small molecules where donor-acceptor substitution leads to lower excited state energies and higher third-order polarizabilities, and it exploits the high molecular densities achieved in single-component assemblies to obtain off-resonant third-order nonlinearities in the final bulk materials that are at least three orders of magnitude larger than silica glass. The properties of the molecules, the resulting evaporated materials, and their relationships are studied with a range of nonlinear optical laser spectroscopy techniques and thin-film characterization methods. Optimized molecular designs lead to evaporated materials with a high, glass-like optical quality that can be combined with existing integrated optics technologies, such as silicon photonics, to add active components for applications such as all-optical switching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project aimed at advancing the understanding of fundamental nonlinear optical properties of small organic molecules and molecular assemblies, and at developing dense, monolithic nonlinear optical materials with high optical quality for integration with nanoscale photonics, with a particular interest towards exploring ways to achieve an electro-optic functionality. The investigation of small molecule assemblies was motivated by the need of adding the speed and flexibility of organic nonlinear optics, including electro-optics, to state-of-the-art integrated optics systems. The need derives from the fact that integration of larger chromophores or polymers with nanoscale photonic structures remains difficult, typically requiring deposition from solution. Small molecule, on the other hand, provide a potentially much more flexible system where any nanoscale structures can be homogeneously and selectively filled via vapor deposition in vacuum. 

The research focused on the fundamental characterization of nonlinear optical effects in small molecules, and on developing the use of the molecules to create high-optical quality nonlinear optical and electro-optic bulk materials via molecular beam deposition into molecular assemblies.

Fundamental investigations at the molecular level. 

This work concentrated on the experimental determination of the wavelength dependence of the full complex-valued third-order susceptibility as it varies with the length of a conjugated system connecting a donor and acceptor group. To do this we developed a novel semi-automatic method based on degenerate four-wave mixing. The experimental data confirmed that donor-acceptor substitution in small molecules leads to orders of magnitude enhancements in nonlinear optical efficiency when compared to non-substituted molecules of similar size. The best efficiency was achieved for conjugated systems consisting of only 1 to 3 multiple bonds. While the nonlinearity of small molecules necessarily remains small compared to larger ones, donor-acceptor substitution guarantees that the nonlinearity is record-high relative to the molecule's size, which then leads to high nonlinear optical activity in dense molecular assemblies. The determination of the full nonlinear optical spectrum around the first two-photon resonance also lead to several interesting observations. Among them the fact that the peak imaginary part of the third-order polarizability (and the corresponding two-photon absorption cross-section) remains relatively constant as the conjugated bridge between donor and acceptor groups grows, leading to a large resonance in the real part. In fact, the peak imaginary part maintains a constant relationship with the off-resonant value of the real part, an effect predicted by the behavior of the fundamental limits for the two quantities. 


Fabrication and characterization of bulk monolithic materials. 

This work was an exploration of how to induce a preferential orientational order and electro-optic functionalities in small molecule assemblies that have otherwise all the characteristics of a high-quality organic glass. The aim  was to determine if it is possible to create, by the application of an electric field during molecular beam deposition, a preferential orientational order in an otherwise amorphous monolithic assembly of small molecules. There was no prior indication that it would be possible to do so before our research, but we then confirmed that this is indeed possible. Experiments used in-situ applied electric fields up to 4 kV/mm, which induced a  preferential orientation that remained constant and reproducible over the whole thickness of the deposited films. Second-order nonlinear optical coefficients of the order of 4 pm/V could be achieved using in-situ poling and an existing non-optimized molecule. This was the first observation that electric-field poling can lead to significant second-order effects in an otherwise amorphous, dense molecular assembly with a high, glass-like optical quality.


In summary, we have shown how to optimize the optical nonlinearity of small molecules (thanks to DA substitution around small conjugated systems) and how to use the same small molecules to create high optical quality thin films via organic molecular beam deposition. This is important for both third-order nonlinear optical applications (e.g. all-optical switching) and to build electro-optic modulators. Since the small-molecule material can be easily incorporated into nanostructured passive waveguiding systems, the type of material that we have pioneered can potentially enter the integrated optics toolbox as a way to add nonlinear optical and electro-optic functionality to existing, passive integrated optics technology (such as the silicon photonics platform).  As an example, an electro-optic modulator could be built by depositing appropriate small molecules into the slot of a silicon slot-waveguide modulator while applying a voltage to the contacts to instill an electro-optic response. Since the typical width of the slot is only  of the order of 100 nm, even a small applied voltage and a relatively small electro-optic coefficient would lead to a refractive index modulation large enough to implement a high-speed electro-optic modulator.
